description: Violoncello Pomposa is listed only by Irwin, who says: A solo form of the Violoncello, at 8' on the manuals. This rich, resonant, big-toned, stringy timbre has a few more overtones in it than the average 'Cello stop. It is one of the loudest Strings in the organ. It may be on the Solo or String windchest, and may make the loudest céleste in the organ. It is usually made fropm metal pipes but wood provides an equally loud, deep, bright-toned effect if the rank is so designed. The name Cello Pomposa does not appear in the literature.
examplesDescription: Cello Pomposa 8', Solo; Convention Hall, Atlantic City, New Jersey, USA; Midmer-Losh 1929-32.
